content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would approach this repeated game strategically, considering the potential outcomes and my opponent's possible strategies.

In this game, it seems that picking R is always beneficial when my opponent picks B, but if they also pick R, both players end up with less money compared to choosing B. However, the fact that I will play 75 rounds suggests that I should take a long-term perspective.

If I consistently choose R in the hopes that my opponent might switch to B eventually (as they would earn more by doing so), I may end up with fewer points than if I choose B. This is because, while picking R when they pick B results in a higher payoff for me, I will only receive this benefit in half of the rounds, and I'll lose out on the 20$ payout for choosing B.

Conversely, if I consistently choose B, my opponent might take advantage of this by always picking R to maximize their earnings. In that case, I would earn 40$ per round they pick R but only 20$ when they also choose B.

To optimize my strategy, I would need to have information about my opponent's preferences or tendencies. However, without such information, a rational approach might be to pick an equal number of R and B as a way to keep my opponent guessing and potentially induce them to switch strategies in order to maximize their earnings.

Ultimately, I would lean towards choosing B more often than R, but with some variations to maintain unpredictability and potentially increase the chances of earning 45$ per round when my opponent picks R as well. My choice for this particular round would be {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.
